metadata.title: Back Pain  Low, Acute
anatomical location body part affected: Lower back can involve several structures, often one or more of the following: the erector spinae and multifidus muscles, lumbar vertebral and lumbosacral joints, pelvis and associated joints, longitudinal ligament, supraspinous and interspinous ligaments, ligamentum flavum, thoracolumbar fascia, annulus fibrosis, zygapophyseal (facet) joints, intervertebral discs, spinal cord, dura mater, and the associated lumbar and sacral spinal nerves

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified. Inquire about any ongoing legal claims, including workers’ compensation
presentation signs and symptoms: Nontraumatic LBP that has been present for less than 6 weeks
Unilateral or bilateral pain: aching, sharp, dull, shooting, or burning
The primary complaint is usually mechanical pain (i.e., aggravated by activity and relieved with rest) –Positions that relieve the patient’s symptoms are referred to as “relief positions”
Pain may radiate or refer to the LE Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Consult with physician in the case of LBP that does not lessen with recumbency
Cauda equina syndrome is a medical emergency that requires immediate evaluation and surgery
Suspicion for osteomyelitis, spinal compression fracture, or abdominal aneurysm (all warrant immediate referral to emergency services)(13)
Severe, progressive, or unresolving neurologic deficits in the lower extremity

Increased pain with straight-leg  raise (SLR). LBP and symptoms before 60˚ are a discal sign, while pain after 60˚ is a mechanical sign. A positive slump sign is associated with a true positive SLR finding. Symptom magnification in sitting with knee extension indicates spinal derangement(1)

causes: Overexertion using back muscles (e.g., strenuous lifting, pulling, or carrying)
Underlying spinal derangement or degenerative joint disease (DJD)(1)
Sacroiliac joint dysfunction or other pelvic girdle pain
Poor posture, body mechanics, and/or ergonomics
pathogenesis ,,: Mechanical and inflammatory reactions make the precise etiology of LBP clinically difficult to determine withoutimaging studies.(1) However, immediate imaging is not recommended for acute LBP because it does not improve clinicaloutcomes(3,13,14)
The exact mechanism of LBP is found in only 12–15%  of patients(2)
In addition to nervous tissue, a variety of spinal structures might generate pain in LBP (e.g., disc, posterior spinal elements,facet joints, and surrounding muscle, ligaments, and fascia)

Lumbar strain–Overstretching and tearing of lumbar muscle, possibly with injury to associated tendons and ligaments, due to excessivestretch or strain–Abnormal spinal curvature, such as in increased lumbar lordosis or scoliosis, can place added torsion on discs, ligaments,and surrounding musculature–Stretching of involved muscles and connective tissue typically increases pain

Lumbar disc disease–Radicular pain or sciatica can occur if disc protrudes, herniates, or ruptures and inflames or compresses the adjacentnerve root; pain might then radiate to the buttock, thigh, calf, and/or foot. Bony or ligamentous tissue can also impinge onnerves–Lumbar flexion may exacerbate symptoms and thus be restricted–For more information, see  Clinical Review…Herniated Disc  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708470

Lumbar spinal stenosis–This is usually a degenerative condition. As DJD progresses, the intraspinal space decreases with disc bulging andinfolding of the ligamentum flavum, resulting in a narrowed spinal canal and nerve root foramen–Abnormal pressure on spinal nerve roots results from a combination of disc degeneration, facet joint arthritis, andsubluxation–Lumbar extension may exacerbate symptoms and thus be restricted–For more information, see  Clinical Review…Spinal Stenosis  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708607

Facet joint syndrome–Synovitis and degeneration of the vertebral facet joints with the development of arthritis–Can develop in conjunction with disc thinning–Lumbar flexion is usually favored over extension–For more information, see  Clinical Review…Facet Joint Pathology  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709032

Sacroiliac joint or other pelvic girdle pain–See  Clinical Review…Sacroiliac Joint Dysfunction  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708569–See  Clinical Review…Pelvic Girdle Pain: An Overview  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708588
Spondylosis–See  Clinical Review…Spondylosis  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T902606

Cauda equina syndrome and some types of myelitis result from extreme nerve root compression or inflammation due totraumatic injury, disc herniation, spinal stenosis, spinal neoplasm/metastatic tumor, infection, or inflammation. Caudaequina syndrome is a medical emergency because it can cause permanent lower extremity paralysis and impairment ofbowel and bladder function(2)–For more information, see  Clinical Review…Cauda Equina Syndrome  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708499
risk factors: Authors of a review of the 2018 literature found numerous potential risk factors for LBP, which could be grouped into 4categories:(42)–Individual (e.g., older age)–Poor general health (e.g., smoking, obesity)–Physical stress on the spine (e.g., prolonged sitting, lifting heaving loads/weights, lifting with improper postures)–Psychological stress (e.g., depression)

Authors of a study (N = 5233) investigated risk factors associated with the transition from acute to chronic LBP in patientsin the United States seeking care from primary care providers.These included obesity, smoking, severe and very severebaseline disability, and diagnosed depression/anxiety(41)

overall contraindications precautions: Consult with physician on finding red flags Red flags for spinal fracture: older age, trauma, corticosteroid use, history of osteoporosis, and contusions and/or abrasions(38) Red flags for spinal malignancy: older age, history of cancer, unexpected weight loss, and failure to improve after 1 month(38) Red flags for infection: intravenous drug use, spinal procedure in the past 12 months, fever, and localized pain and tenderness(38) Red flags for cauda equina syndrome: progressive motor or sensory loss, new urinary retention or overflow incontinence, new fecal incontinence,saddle anesthesia, loss of anal sphincter tone, and significant motor deficits encompassing multiple nerve roots(38) Pregnancy  Bilateral sciatica or leg weakness

Be aware of ”yellow flags” or psychosocial, workplace, and other risk factors for persistent pain, transition to chronic condition, and prolonged disability (e.g., depression, fear-avoidance  beliefs, and pain catastrophizing)(13,19)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Consult with physician in the case of LBP that does not lessen with recumbency
Cauda equina syndrome is a medical emergency that requires immediate evaluation and surgery
Suspicion for osteomyelitis, spinal compression fracture, or abdominal aneurysm (all warrant immediate referral to emergency services)(13)
Severe, progressive, or unresolving neurologic deficits in the lower extremity

Increased pain with straight-leg  raise (SLR). LBP and symptoms before 60˚ are a discal sign, while pain after 60˚ is a mechanical sign. A positive slump sign is associated with a true positive SLR finding. Symptom magnification in sitting with knee extension indicates spinal derangement(1)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document when the patient first experienced LBP. What was the patient doing at the time of onset? Was the onset sudden, due to trauma or accident, or did LBP develop gradually for no known reason? What has been the duration of LBP? Has the patient experienced this pain before?

course of treatment.medical management: Document the history of medical interventions for this condition. What treatments have or have not been effective?
course of treatment.medications: Document the prescribed medications and identify those not being taken. Are those being taken effective? Oral opioid analgesics (e.g., tramadol, oxycodone) and injectable corticosteroids (e.g., dexamethasone, triamcinolone [Kenalog], methylprednisolone [DepoMedrol])  might be trialed in severe cases. Has the patient received any injectable or opioid medications for pain relief?
diagnostic tests completed: Clinicians should refrain from immediate lumbar imaging in patients with acute or subacute LBP without features suggesting a serious red flag underlying condition such as fracture.(3,15) However, imaging might be indicated if patients show no improvement after 6 weeks(13,14,15)
MRI is useful in revealing disc herniation(2)
Researchers who conducted a prospective, population-based  cohort study in the United States found that having an

early MRI in the absence of red flags (which is considered nonadherent  to current guidelines) was associated with increased likelihood of injections, surgery, or higher costs for outpatient, inpatient, and nonmedical services and disability compensation(15)

Researchers in Italy describe a dynamic MRI with an open configuration in which the patient can be upright. This tool is useful for patients with a negative MRI in the recumbent position or for patients with pain in the upright position only(16)
Advanced imaging and primary management for LBP was found to be associated with higher healthcare utilization and charges than physical therapy(25)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heat pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture, chiropractic medicine) and whether they have helped The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines on LBP do not recommend acupuncture as a treatment(30) Researchers who conducted a clinical trial (n = 275 patients with nonspecific acute LBP) in Spain found no difference after a 2week  period of intervention with true acupuncture, sham acupuncture, or placebo acupuncture for pain relief(11) Researchers who conducted an RCT in Korea found that motion style acupuncture treatment has positive effects on immediate pain relief and functional recovery of patients with acute LBP and severe disability(17)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Inquire about any positions or activities that aggravate or alleviate symptoms. Pain associated with lumbar DJD is aggravated by activity, coughing, and sneezing, and relieved with rest. Pain associated with facet joint syndrome is commonly aggravated by side-bending  or lumbar spinal extension, whereas lumbar spinal stenosis is aggravated by walking or lumbar spinal extension
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Pain associated with lumbar disc disease is localized near the disc and may refer to the iliac crest or buttock. Pain associated with lumbar spine stenosis is located in the low back with cramping in the leg. Facet joint syndrome pain is commonly localized to the facet
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Symptoms include pain, tenderness, weakness, and lower extremity cramping. In general, are symptoms improving, worsening, or staying the same?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to this condition. Inquire about sleep position and pillow use. Refer patient back to physician if he/she has excessive or unrelenting night pain
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., fever, dizziness, fatigue, nausea, sudden worsening of symptoms, weight loss of unknown origin, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia, night pain, pain at rest)(1) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Ask patient if he/she has a history of LBP, how long previous symptoms were present, and number of recurrences
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, cardiovascular disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic issues. Document gastrointestinal symptoms, genitourinary symptoms, and general systemic complaints (fever, weight loss, peripheral joint symptoms, etc.) Inquire about family history of ankylosing spondylitis in younger patients with reduced side bending and report of the need to get out of bed frequently at night(14)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken currently, including OTC drugs
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in sports? What does patient’s job or daily activities require? Does patient spend extended time in one position doing repetitive activity, such as sitting at a computer?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: ›Relevant tests and measures (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting):
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Measure height and weight. Determine BMI and whether patient is overweight or obese. Also measure for leg-length  discrepancy
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document whether patient uses a lumbar support or any assistive devices
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static/dynamic balance in sitting and standing, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess peripheral pulsesAssess lumbosacral neural tension with SLR in supine. Pain produced before 70° hip flexion, aggravated by dorsiflexion of the ankle and relieved by flexion of the knee, indicates sciatic nerve root tension and involvementObserve posture and body mechanics with general mobility and with movements that patient reports aggravate symptoms, such as lifting and carrying. Inquire about work station setup, perform ergonomic assessment as indicated
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess as indicated for any deficits, use FIM for objective measurements
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess for gait abnormalities/asymmetries that may be contributing to dysfunctionAssess segmental mobility of thoracic and lumbar spine with posterior-to-anterior  glides as indicated and appropriate; note movement and pain.(13) Clear involvement of the hip and sacroiliac joints
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess bilateral LE and trunk strength using manual muscle testing (MMT), as tolerated
observation inspection palpation includi: Observe for abnormalities in lumbosacral surface anatomy
Palpate for tenderness and trigger points, as well as symmetry of bony landmarks of the pelvis
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Note any postural abnormalities or asymmetries, or abnormal spinal curvature (i.e., scoliosis, listing, kyphosis, or lordosis). A fiber-optic  device was found effective for measuring lumbar curvature changes during trunk flexion and extension and lifting movements in patients with acute or chronic LBP.(8) A significant reduction in kyphosis at end-range flexion and lifting was noted in patients with acute LBP following pain relief (oral analgesics), although peak curvature and lumbar sequencing behavior were not affected(9) –Assess for leg-length  symmetry and level of iliac crests and any other landmarks –Leaning away from the painful side in standing, with the hip and knee slightly flexed on the affected side, may indicate nerve root compression(1)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Assess full bilateral LE ROM, including passive hip internal and external rotation, flexion, and extension(13) –Document reproduction of pain –Measure amount of active lumbar flexion, extension, and side-bending  with an inclinometer(13) –In standing, assess forward bending, measuring distance from fingertips to the floor. While patient is flexed, view from behind to detect scoliosis and from the side to detect persistent lumbar lordosis, indicative of protective muscle guarding –Assess lumbar ROM using Schober’s test, making marks 5 cm above and below the L5–S1  junction and measuring the distance between the two marks with patient in neutral position and while bending forward(1) –Measure trunk extension, rotation, and side-bending  to the right and left. Pain while bending toward the affected side may indicate disc disease, and pain while bending away from affected side may indicate muscular strain(1) –Test flexibility of hamstrings, iliotibial bands, quadriceps, hip rotators, and hip flexors using 90–90  SLR and Ober, Ely, and Thomas tests
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess patellar and Achilles reflexes in sitting position. Hyporeflexia indicates lower motor neuron involvement. Note the presence or absence of clonus (upper motor neuron involvement)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess sensation (pinprick, light touch, and temperature) along lower extremity dermatomes
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: –SLR test(13) –Slump test(13) –V ASThis index was developed on patients with chronic LBP for both assessment and outcome(13)This is a health status measure to assess physical disability due to LBP. It is designed to be completed by patient(13) –Short Form 36 (SF-36)  Health Survey(13)  –FABQ(13) –Pain Catastrophizing Scale(13) –Quebec Back Pain Disability Scale(13) –Orebro Musculoskeletal Pain Questionnaire(OMPQ)(13,18) -Researchers in Hong Kong found that the OMPQ could predict return to work outcomes better than the RMDQ, numerical pain scores, FABQ, and Numeric Global Rate of Change (NGRC), and should be used to identify high-risk individuals(18)

contraindications precautions: Raynaud’s syndrome
Over area of circulatory compromise
Over an area of peripheral vascular disease
Cold intolerance
Cryoglobulinemia
Cold urticaria
Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria
Avoid applying cold over superficial nerves
Hypertension
Thermoregulatory disorders
Over a superficial peripheral nerve
Over an open wound
Over an area of poor sensation
With individuals with poor cognition
In the very young or very old
Persons with aversion to cold
Application over areas with a lack of intact thermal sensation
Application over areas of vascular insufficiency or vascular disease
Application over areas of recent hemorrhage or potential hemorrhage
Application over areas of known malignancy
Application over areas of acute inflammation
Application over infected areas where infection may spread or cross-contamination  may occur
Application over areas where liniments or heat rubs have recently been applied
Application in any situation deemed unreliable by the practitioner
other: Tailor the exercise prescription to fit the patient’s functional ability and tolerance. Provide close supervision with instruction during exercise therapy and functional training sessions to ensure proper posture and technique and that the patient maintains a stable core
Provide the patient with a thorough orientation to use of therapeutic exercise equipment and with adequate warm-up  time to help reduce the patient’s apprehension about exercise
Modify exercise sessions to minimize movement-related  pain
Clinicians should follow the exercise guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician
Contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis regarding use of modalities are mentioned below. Rehabilitation clinicians should always use their professional judgment in decision making

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Acute LBP and restricted functional mobility that negatively impact physical functioning; reduced trunk and LE flexibility, ROM, and strength; poor posture, body mechanics, and ergonomics; inability to return to work and perform ADLs
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Spinal tumors Ankylosing spondylitis Myelitis Cauda equina syndrome Referred pain from kidneys, prostate, female pelvic organs, gastrointestinal tract, pancreas, and abdominal aortic aneurysm Psychologic chronic pain syndrome
prognosis: The prognosis in acute LBP is good, with recovery for most patients, but 10% of patients are at risk for developing chronic LBP(36)

Psychological factors such as fear avoidance and self-efficacy  may influence outcomes of patients with LBP(36) –Authors of a study (N = 418) examined the role of fear-avoidance  beliefs and self-efficacy  on pain and physical functioning in patients with acute and chronic LBP receiving physical therapy(36) -At discharge from physical therapy, patients with chronic LBP had a lower functional status, lower self-efficacy  for physical function, and higher pain intensity compared to patients with acute LBP. There was no difference between groups in fear-avoidance beliefs -Self-efficacy  may be an important influence on outcomes in patients with chronic LBP. Implementing strategies to improve self-efficacy  in physical therapy may improve pain

Authors of a study (N = 85) researched military members with LBP to identify factors that help to identify patients who will have a favorable outcome. Each patient took part in an exercise program that consisted of 2–3 sessions weekly with a physical therapist for 6 weeks(37) –Five factors helped to identify patients who were likely to have a favorable outcome: no pain when lying down, no use of antidepressants, FABQ work score ˂ 22.5, fewer than 5 physical therapy sessions before entering the program, and less than 6 months of work restriction

In a 2012 systematic review, researchers found that the odds that adults with acute or subacute non-specific  LBP and negative recovery expectations are twice as likely to remain absent from work due to progression to chronic LBP than those with more positive expectations(12)

Researchers who conducted a review in 2013 found that LBP transitioning from acute to chronic is more closely related to demographic, psychosocial, and occupational factors than to the medical characteristics of the low back disorder itself. They recommended that these dimensions be evaluated, with the goal of identifying those patients at risk for chronicity(19)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines A multidisciplinary approach to treatment of acute LBP might include the referring physician and the consulting surgeon, a pain management specialist, a psychologist, an occupational therapist, a physical therapist, and/or a vocational rehabilitation counselor Orthopedic surgeon or neurosurgeon for consultation regarding recurrent disc herniation, spinal stenosis, or segmental lumbar instability
other considerations: NICE clinical guidelines do not recommend the use of electrotherapies (ultrasound, percutaneous electric nerve stimulation [PENS], transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation [TENS], and interferential current) in the treatment of LBP(30)

Researchers who conducted a clinical trial in the United Kingdom found that usual chiropractic care (UCC) was equally effective as a chiropractic care protocol (CCP) based on practice guidelines in patients with acute LBP of less than 6 weeks’ duration(6) –One hundred eighteen participants were randomly assigned to the CCP and UCC groups –Patients in each group received up to seven manipulative and manual therapy treatments over 4 weeks –At 4 weeks’ follow-up,  ODI scores were not significantly different between groups and patient satisfaction was equally high (85%) in both groups
While physical therapy can reduce LBP and increase function, researchers in the United States found that out-of-pocket costs negatively predict physical therapy utilization(24)

Researchers of an RCT study conducted in Korea compared the use of an intra-articular  lumbar facet joint pulsed radiofrequency to intra-articular  corticosteroid injections and concluded that both interventions can effectively reduce pain in patients experiencing lumbar facet joint pain, with the effects lasting up to 6 months(28)  –Sixty patients were randomized to either the intra-articular pulsed radiofrequency group (N = 30) or intra-articular corticosteroid injections group (N = 30) –Patients were given the respective treatments and were followedup at 2 weeks and 1, 3, and 6 months, using a numerical pain score
treatment summary: NICE guidelines for the treatment of LBP recommend:(30) –Patient education: reassurance on positive outcomes, return to normal activities, and avoidance of bed rest –Exercise: adapt to each patient’s individual needs –Manual therapy:spinal manipulation, mobilizations, and/or soft tissue mobilizations can be considered in addition to an exercise program –Psychological treatments: consider approaches such as cognitive behavior therapy (CBT), but with an exercise program

Treatment techniques recommended in the Orthopedic section of the American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) current practice guidelines, based on peer-reviewed  literature, include the following:(13) –Manual therapy –Trunk coordination, strengthening, and endurance exercises –Centralization and directional preference exercises and procedures -Flexion exercises -Extension exercises –Lower-quarter  neural mobilizations –Patient education and counseling –Progressive endurance exercise and fitness activities

The Ontario Protocol for Traffic Injury Management (OPTIMa) Collaboration conducted a systematic review between 2005 and 2014 and created best-evidence  guidelines for managing low back symptoms, which include patient education on self-management  and return to activity(27)
Preventing acute LBP from becoming chronic is the key for all treatments. Early physical therapy interventionhas positive

maintenance or prevention: Continue exercises found effective and well tolerated to maintain optimal physical functioning(14)
The use of shoe insoles, rocker sole shoes, and lumbar supports is not recommended for the prevention of LBP(30)
